When I was in the military I was at a Waterpark with friends when a toddler had a seizure and fell underwater. Fortunately he was pulled out but by the time I got to him he had already inhaled a large amount of water. My training kicked in and I was able to get him to expel a large amount of water and bring him inside. He continued to have seizures but he could breathe. I just placed him in a rescue position and calmed him aunt and uncle while we waited for EMS to arrive. Thankfully the boy was ok. Hopefully they were able to treat his seizures and he has continued to live a good life. He'd be about 18 now.

After a lot of work by the EMTs and emergency room medical staff they got her back and she stabilized. My mother had seizures when she was alive. One day, she literally had a seizure while she was driving the car with me and my brother. I was in the front seat and my brother was in the back seat. Me and him had to work together to save her, and ourselves. I took my momâ€™s foot off the gas with my hands and reached down past her legs to control the pedals and push the breaks, and my brother stirred the wheel from the backseat into a parking lot. We parked the car, called for help, and waited until the seizure subsided. It still amazes me at how calm we were and how quickly we took action at such young ages. My brother was about 14 and I was about 11-12 at the time. RIP momma ğŸŒ¹

Imagine that car had been pushed over a bridge guardrail about 40 feet above. It was upside down. All the doors had seized up when crushed as the roof rolled over the guardrail. I was unable to open the doors and no one was in reach when i went as far into the car ss I could includi g the rear seat arra. Another person joined tbe effort and both of us together could not open the crushed doors. He stood on tbe bottom of the car and it was chest deep for him.  It went over in front of me.I was a 15 yr old HS Senior. The cops, fire truck and divers showed up. They ordered us out of the water. The firetruck dragged the car out upside down. The man was on the back window ledge. They took him to a nearby hospital.  I described how it happened to the accident investigator. He did not believe me. I explained it as basic physiics. i insisted I was correct and re-explained how it occurred several times. I later lrarned that later an accident expert from tbis county travelled the country teaching this method of stopping cars as the Pitt Manuever. I finally found two earlier people who used this twchnique. The Romanian Secret Police taught it to their people. And stock car drivers used it in the early 1950's.  So the hidtory of the common police manuever.  I know hhow i feel years later dredging this up. I didn't know the man. Tha child was dealing witj it being his mom. He will always remember that and the gpod resolution. Best wishes.

Aww God bless
1 in 26 americans will develop epilepsy in their lifetime. For some of us- They strike months or even years apartâ€‹. My first seizure wasn't until 28 yo and the second was 8 months later. When you've never had one before- You don't understand "auras" and don't realize it's a warning that something terrible is about to happen. The unlucky ones don't get auras, therefore no warning. There are many types of seizures, other than grand mal's (seen in movies). They all look different, and looking these up could save someones life- Even a loved ones!  -Do not restrain people in active seizure. Instead, put them on their side incase they foam at the mouth. Place something under their head if they are hitting it and move away anything that they could hurt themselves on.  - Do NOT try to keep someone from "choking on their tongue". Thats a myth.  - Time the seizure if you can. How many minutes was it. When they stop-Start timing again bc if they have a second seizure within 5 minutes that's a HUGE red flag and drs will need that info. Obvs time following seizures/inbetweens as well.

This is representative of our men and women in blue. They don't hesitate to rush in to help whether it's an accident, health issue, or crime in progress. Their own safety is secondary to the person they're trying to help. When a incident arises where a subject is being violent towards those in the community, themselves, or our officers those officers, in a majority of cases, have mere seconds to make life and death decisons. At the very least our officers deserve the benefit of the doubt not the nonsensical Democrat propaganda aimed at not only defunding police depts but also demonizing our officers. A simple thank you is more appropriate. At this stage it would be nice if they acknowledged their divisive rhetoric has resulted in a severe drop in new applicants and a rash of retirments/career changes. Departments running on low numbers of officers result in the community being subjected to higher rates of crime as evidenced by the astronomical jump in crime.

Salute to the Good Samaritan. In 2014 a girl leaving Lauberge Casino in Lake Charles, La flipped her car off the end 210 bridge and I stopped with 1 other guy. She was completely unconscious and her car was already on fire. While we were trying to get her out a couple others ran up to help. We got her through her window (dress was on fire, legs burned) and carried her about 20 feet before the car completely went into flames. Once EMS got there and she was loaded into the ambulance I left. The other guys waited for news people to come and did their 15 minutes of fame on TV. They acted they were first there and did everything. The only person that mentioned me was the officer that was first on scene which Iâ€™m thankful for. My mind was never on getting on the news in that situation. She lived and ended up writing me on FB about 6-7 months afterward.

Everything for a Reason!  Theyâ€™re Blessed and this is a Heroic boy
I have epilepsy. Ive always had the random hard body jerks but just like 2 or 3 at a time. Then August 2010 i had a barely 5 and barely 8 year old kids. We left Oklahoma for southern Louisiana to spend a week woth my cousins. We got there close to 1 am. I got the kids in bed and took my meds. Then grabbed a cold bottle of water and went outside to have a cig with my cousin. After I finished it I said i wasn't feeling well. I stood up and just made it to the door when i started having a seizure. I knew what was going on. I fell on the chainsaw blades and could feel the pain and could feel the door handle in my hand. I came to and walked into the house and slid down the wall to sut on the cold concrete floor in the kitchen. I remember putting my bottle of water into my tennis shoe and the next thing I remember is my cousin slapping me and yelling for her husband. Ive had a few big ones since then. My last big one I broke my foot and somehow came to sitting on the lid of the toilet. No clue how that happened. I still have the big annoying sometimes painful jerks but I haven't had a big one since summer 2022. Keppra has helped SO much. But all these years it has worried me that it will happen when I'm driving. Thankfully I've learned what I feel like before a big one hits. I don't drive out of town unless someone is with me. Shoot the only time I'm in a car alone is if my Mom doesn't ride with me to get my oldest from work 4 days a week. I sure hope this Momma is ok.
Now how is somebody trapped under water supposed to answer when asked "is somebody there"?

Don't drive anymore if a Seizure could happen while doing so.
DETAILS/UPDATE: Jonquetta Winbush, the Texas mom and her two children, 16-year-old daughter Bri-Asia, and her 12-year-old son Dwight, were on route on July 24 in West Orange, Texas when Winbush had a seizure and veered off the road. Dwight was able to swim out of the car as his sister told him to call 9-1-1.   Police officer Charles Cobb arrived, as you saw, flagged down by Dwight. The officer was able to punch out a window but it caused water to flood into the car. A few drivers also on route, saw this happening, and jumped in to assist. They eventually got the front door open and pulled the lifeless Winbush out and began CPR.   On scene, they were able to get a pulse, ambulances were called, and Winbush spent 3 weeks on a ventilator where her sister Bevnisha Holman reported she is getting stronger and now breathing on her own.   Bevnisha personally thanked those involved for helping save her sister, and care for her niece, and nephew.   The city of West Orange honored Cobb and the good Samaritans on Aug. 13 with a life-saving award and letter of commendation.

For the people like "why is he so slow? Why is he so calm?" Well for the people who don't know, we are trained to stay calm and access the danger. The cop was mostly likely thinking of a plan to help the mom in the car. The only thing that pissed me off was the cop asking "if anyone was in there" and not "how many people are in there" us first responders NEED to stay calm so we can properly access the danger and make a proper safe plan. If we just go in Willy Nilly we can make mistakes. So would you rather he went in without a plan which could potentially put everyone, not just the mother in the car, in danger? Or would you rather he take a few seconds/minutes to make a proper plan that won't put anymore lives in danger? Idk about you but I'd rather they make a proper plan so no other lives are in danger than them go in without a plan potentially putting others lives in danger.

If she was known to have seizures, she shouldn't be driving.  Another failure of the healthcare system.   Seizures, heart attacks, strokes and other medical conditions are supposed to be reported to DMV.  Where liscense is usually temporarily suspended until medical clearance has been confirmed.   Same goes for mental health issues and possession of firearms.  Where 90% of mass shootings had prior knowledge of mental health issues yet not one reported to proper authorities.

I usually wait a year just in case, it makes me less anxious knowing Iâ€™ve made it a year vs 6 months. But this is my absolute biggest fear driving with my son. Heâ€™s only 12 but Iâ€™ve taught him what to do if this ever happens while Iâ€™m driving. Iâ€™ve been having them since he was born and he just saw me have a seizure for the first time last year. He was next to me in bed one morning and before I have one I have a few seconds to warn someone that itâ€™s going to happen. I live with my dad so as soon as I felt one coming on I yelled get grampa Iâ€™m gunna have a seizure. He hauled ass down the hall told my dad, my dad called 911 and my son came back. He held my hand the entire seizure and made sure my head stayed on my pillow. Once I come out of it Iâ€™m post ictal, which is between the seizure and returning to normal almost like your memory gets completely wiped and he was just standing next to the bed telling me I was okay over and over. It takes months for lungs to dry out when they fill with water. The inside of human lungs are very delicate, kind of like tissue paper. Of course, infection and pneumonia are a big concern, especially when someone breathed pond water. This woman thankfully survived, according to the  comments.      I knew a guy who was knocked unconscious when his boat was hit by another boat at high speed. He was underwater for at least 8 minutes. Somehow he survived, but his lungs took several months until they were back to normal. There was no detectable brain damage. One in a million people survive that long underwater, but he made a full recovery. That's ridiculously rare.

Summary with update: It happened on July 24, 2024 in West Orange, Texas. You don't see the cop run to his cruiser to get a window breaking tool. He comes back to the car, breaks the back window when the car began to sink. He & at least 2 good samaritans were able to pull her out (a real feat in itself with a limp body submerged in a car!), where she was unconscious, not breathing, but a light pulse on her wrist. After being rescued, the mom of 2, Jonquetta Winbush, was placed on a ventilator for 3 weeks before being able to breathe on her own. At this time, she is still recovering. The cop, Charles Cobb, & the good samaritans were awarded with a life-saving award and letter of commendation on Aug. 13, 2024. *That is her 12yo son who had been in the car & escaped. Her 16yo daughter was also with her & told her brother to call for help.

PSA: To anyone who is conscious when the car goes into the water.  DO NOT struggle with the getting the doors open.  That is wasting too much time & energy.  â€¦ Thereâ€™s a reason the trunk/end of the car always stays up as the car is sinking. & the back window glass is made different, easier to break.  â€¦ Itâ€™s because of this scenario exactly.  Crawl to the back of the car, bust out back window & go out that way.  & also.   If youâ€™re too weak to break the glass, pull down the back seat, go into your trunk & pull the lever thatâ€™s inside of trunk, to pop it open.  DO NOT stay in the front of your car.   &. You can buy a handheld device, that will break the glass windows in your vehicle, if you ever get trapped in it. The device is inexpensive & worth every penny.  â€¦ Keep In middle console, or, cubby hole/pocket of driver/passenger door, easy access area.  .. I keep mine in middle console.   I hope this is shared to others, so it can possibly safe a live in the future.

For years I didn't drive because of my seizures. People have constantly told me that I'm a horrible person and selfish for not driving. They tell me seizures aren't a real excuse. This is the EXACT reason why some people who have seizures should never drive. I hit the windshield when I was 17 because of my epilepsy and never drove again. If someone tells you they cannot drive because of a medical reason, just because you can't see that reason immediately,  do not shame them, or put them down or make excuses. This here is the literal proof of just how dangerous those medical conditions can be. Imagine if this would have been in heavy, fast-paced traffic. Imagine if it was a bus driver with children. This just enforces my hurt of the shame and hate I have recieved from family, friends and strangers who think they know better.
Cop needs better training and to learn how to operate at speed...Sincerely, LE Instructor

I'm a person who was a passenger in a car with a person who had a seizure. Luckily it was peak time traffic and the car slowly went into a bollard. I didn't even know this person had epilepsy. This is going to sound harsh but I think people who suffer from epilepsy or who can pass out from low sugar due to diabetes should make their potential passengers aware of these problems. I can see when a person is too drunk to drive and can assess the risk and decline to be a passenger. I cannot assess the risk to my safety if I don't know about your health conditions. It is different with heart attacks and strokes. That is unexpected medical emergencies, but epilepsy and diabetes sugar drops is a known risk which you know you have and I should have the option to decide if I want to risk my own personal safety.

Before we knew my husband was hypoallergenic and seizure prone one morning he took our 6 yr old son our 5 yr old daughter and 10 day old new born baby girl and strapped them into truck. 3 blocks from home he started having a seizure at the wheel he hit a PowerPoint with foot on full gas head on. They hadn't been gone 4 minutes and I get a phone call telling me my husband just hit a pole head on. I ran there barefooted I didn't recognize the truck. And didn't see my family. BY THE GRACE AND MERCY OF GOD, my husband was in the ambulance he was injured pretty bad but he would leave the hospital with me that day. You guys ALL 3 OF OUR BABIES were inside someone's home right on the seen and our son had a cut on his chin. Other then that our babies were not hurt AT ALL. I thought I had just lost my whole family when I seen that truck. Bur God wrapped his arms around them and they lived. That was 15 years ago and I still have my husband and we have our babies..now thier grown. God's work

This is exactly why they should have stricter laws against allowing people with a seizure condition to get a driver's license. They're not only putting their own lives in danger, but they are putting their children's lives in danger or whoever they have as passengers as well as strangers on the road. It's as bad and as selfish as deciding to drink and drive as it is to decide to drive knowing you could have a seizure at any time. Of course I thank God her child is safe and it looks like she got saved, but she shouldn't have been driving in the first place. She's clearly had frequent seizures because her young son knew exactly what it was that happened and why she wrecked, so why would she even put her baby in such a deadly situation that's child neglect and child endangerment. This video edited out some parts and details. She actually had two kids in the car when she crashed. A 16-year-old daughter who remained by the side of the car in the water until police arrived and a 12-year-old son who had gone to flag down the police. Plus two workers helped pulled the mother out, not the cop.   â€œJonquetta Winbushâ€™s two children, a 12-year-old boy and 16-year-old girl, managed to get out while Winbush was having a seizure in late July, West Orange, Texas, Assistant Police Chief Jessie Romero said Wednesday. Winbush then passed out and put her foot on the gas pedal, plunging her vehicle into the pond.  Body camera footage from veteran patrolman Charles Cobb, who was nearby monitoring traffic, shows Winbushâ€™s son frantically approaching the officer.  â€œSheâ€™s having a seizure. Sheâ€™s sunk,â€ the boy told Cobb. â€œSheâ€™s in the water. Help her.â€  Cobb put the boy in the back of his patrol car and raced to Winbushâ€™s vehicle, which was almost completely underwater. Two workers from a local plant had already gotten in the water to get Winbush out, Romero said. According to reports the mom suffered a seizure and went into the water. Her 16 yr old daughter and 12 yr old son were able to get out and flag down the officer. After putting the boy in the patrol car he went to rescue the woman. 2 other plant workers also attempted to help. The officer got the unconscious woman out and did CPR until EMS arrived. She is in the hospital and expected to make a full recovery. Thanks to veteran patrolman Charles Cobb for his quick action.

Is that how he would want someone responding if he was in that car? We know it's not. The officer's urgency only escalated once he committed to helping when he entered that water but especially when realizing his ego was threatened by looking less useful than a citizen already working on it. No other threat was there to slow him down. Of course danger can happen anywhere. Maybe a alligator or a snake or an underwater bomb or the drowning mama might try to shoot her way out. Thank God another adult was there who cared more about saving her life than all the dangers in the universe. You all can praise the officer all day long, But the fact of the matter is he isn't responding out of the kindness of his heart and definitely not in a heartfelt manner. He is responding because he has to because he's on the clock, getting paid for a job he chose to have in life. And, it's more than apparent. Thank God that another adult was there who jumped in to help someone in need because it was the right thing to do as a decent human being..
When you have a seizure disorder and tell people that it's not safe to drive but they bully you with ,well you just don't want it badly enough, you're lazy, just do it,i know someone BS,that's no excuse,you still need too,what kind of adult are you,stop being so soft etc. So,you try to power through and end up at the bottom of a pond. Before deciding to be an AH ,understand that some people do have disabilities, it's not an excuse or way out,you don't get to decide what a disability is and who has it,simply telling people that they don't have a condition ( especially without knowing),doesn't cure them. You don't need to know what someone has,you don't need to be abusive, no one needs to be vulnerable around you,no one owes you full disclosure.  I'm saying that because it happens to me a lot too and it absolutely destroys vulnerable people using their entire strength to function at minimum settings,i don't need to hear all of that BS or be destroyed at first try,second try or at all.
